perfume genius is the musical project of
multi-instrumentalist Mike had rias
super edgy very genius this is his third
full-length album and I have been hotly
anticipating this record considering I
am a big fan of his songwriting style
his two previous full lengths learning
and put your back into it each album a
heartbreak in every song on these
records a teardrop Mike songs typically
are kind of short skeletal
instrumentally and melodically a lot of
these songs sort of revolve around some
very simple piano chords and Mike's
incredibly powerful and emotionally
charged voice and the chords that Mike
works into his songs they're often
played at a very slow or easygoing pace
these progressions at times feel like
they're informed a little bit by gospel
music or maybe even some vintage pop on
his latest songs mike has been finding
ways to build up his typically simple
piano led tunes with a lot of backing
instrumentation and Mike's embrace of
that studio sound quality of better
sound quality in his music has led to a
bit of a night and day difference on his
first two records Mike continues down
the path he was forging on put your back
into it essentially finding new ways to
put lush instrumentation behind his very
emotionally choked up dirges and Mike
also has a few musical experiments up
his sleeves on this record - which is
funny to think because he's not wearing
sleeves
however the opening track on this LP
just kicks this album off in usual
perfume genius fashion the song I
decline is a beautiful spacious piano
ballad with Mike singing some very
sparse lyrics he sings very slowly and
it makes it seem almost as if he's
saying more than what he actually is but
the lines of this track are pretty bare
the message is pretty simple no no
thanks I decline he seems to decline a
tired line he declines what seems like
an offer from an angel to save him I
don't know if he's saying no to the
cliche or if he is saying no to the idea
of salvation in general either way it
means for another perfume genius album
where Mike essentially grabs happiness
by the horns and wrestles it down to the
ground in tintin tintin but learning
from the success of past singles such as
hood mike has made sure to put plenty of
tracks on this new record that are
actually quite visceral Mike delivers
his most instrumentally dense tracks yet
on this LP and inadvertently I think the
end result is kind of poppy
maybe perfume geniuses most accessible
record yet there's some really prominent
percussion on these tracks and the
backing instrumentation is no longer as
faint as it was as put your back into it
take this on Queen for example great
lead single from this LP buzzing
keyboard notes on this track some really
dramatic drum fills some descending epic
mystical synthesizer melodies and a
really explosive chorus - that is not
only loaded with the strange way
melodies but also what seems like a kind
of backing up the percussion and the
lyrics of this track are actually pretty
interesting too it kind of seems like
mike is painting this picture of a
flawed crumbling emotionally inept
matriarch moving on from this track to
the song fool which has a seriously
vintage feel to it like a piece of
vintage pop from the finger snaps to the
saxophones to the upright bass this song
feels old school the song moves pretty
quickly through a very brief and
beautiful verse and then right in the
middle of these two verses on the song
all of a sudden things just go ethereal
and Mike's voice just climbs up and up
and up it's almost as if we've had a
dream sequence in the middle of a song I
love the song my body which is maybe the
most experimental track on the entire
record feels almost as if the song was
written by timbre Tambor and Xu Shu and
then handed over to Mike to perform this
song has a 3/4 time signature eerie
bassline some of Mike's most twisted
vocals and lyrics yet it's like a racer
head sick on the song long Pig we see
Mike's singing over these really tightly
wound bubbling synthesizer sequences
that sound like they could have come out
of a Vangelis song or a tangerine
Dream's song but there's some very
primal percussion going on in the
background Mike does a fantastic job of
mixing these two worlds the futuristic
and just the the very primeval and
another strange track but maybe one that
I don't necessarily connect with is I'm
a mother a song where Mike's vocals
seemed to be just pitched so far
downward they're kind of unintelligible
and he sings with his voice just
cracking and it's like he could barely
hold the note he's just so distraught he
just can't hold it together
and it's the oddest sounding thing so
there are definitely quite a few new
ideas there are a lot of firsts on this
perfume genius record there are actually
a handful of songs on this thing that
approach four minutes in length which is
kind of a rarity in the perfume genius
discography even the songs on this
record that stick to Mike's typically
simple formula of just heart-wrenching
piano ballets kind of get uplifted a
little bit
at least toward the end where all of a
sudden they break into a different
musical phrase or introduce really epic
instrumentation songs like no good or
don't let them in but I do have my
reservations about this record I think
that with Mike extending more songs and
trying to write longer songs there are
some tracks that stay engaging
throughout and there are some that don't
plus even with the introduction of more
instrumentation it's not like Michaels
songwriting style at its core has
changed that much so there is a little
bit of melodic deja vu here and there on
this record if you're familiar with
Mike's back catalogue while I have no
doubt that Mike can and will change
moving into the future which is
exemplified by tracks like grid there
are some songs here that kind of show
that Mike's approach to writing piano
tunes can be a little limited at times
and there are some moments here namely
on the song no good where I feel like
the bit of instrumentation or maybe the
instrumental interlude or the
instrumental shift toward the end of the
track feels a little kind of tacked on
but for the most part this is perfume
genius sounding emotional and gorgeous
as usual while I do personally prefer
his last full-length album a little bit
more I think this record is great as
well and I highly recommend it I'm
feeling a strongly to a light 9 on this
LP transition if you given this album a
listen what do you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's it
